citation.article-title: Desulfomonile limimaris sp. nov., an anaerobic dehalogenating bacterium from marine sediments.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Desulfomonile limimaris sp. nov.
Desulfomonile limimaris (li.mi.ma'ris. L. n. limus mud; L. neut. n. mare the sea; M.L. gen. limimaris of mud from the sea, referring to the isolation of the organism from marine sediment)
Cells are Gram-negative, non-motile rods, 6-8 μm long and 0.4-0.6 μm wide.
A collar structure girdles each cell.
Growth is obligately anaerobic. 3CB is reductively dechlorinated to benzoate.
Benzoate, lactate, formate, H2, butyrate, propionate and pyruvate are used as electron donors.
Sulfate, sulfite, thiosulfate, nitrate, fumarate and 3CB serve as electron acceptors for growth.
The organism grows at concentrations of NaCl ranging from 0.32 to 2.5%, with optimum growth occurring at 1.25% NaCl.
Strain DCB-MT is the type strain and has been deposited in the American Type Culture Collection as strain ATCC 700979T.
The organism was isolated from marine sediment at Gulf Breeze, FL, USA.
